_meta.description: Enriched edge properties for all Indebtedness Covenant relationships — per-basket activation contexts, stacking mechanics, structural constraints, and negotiation sensitivity
_meta.methodology: Consolidated 45 indebtedness-touching edges from shared relationship graph (sourced from 16 independent analyses) into 19 logically distinct enriched edges. Each edge is decomposed by basket type and structural layer, using 62-deal DealData (100% coverage on 8 keys), 3 expert extractions, and institutional authority documents. All quantitative references expressed as % of LTM EBITDA for cross-deal comparability.

basket_registry._description: The 13 structural components of the Indebtedness Covenant, organized by the three structural layers that determine total debt capacity.

layer_1_fixed_baskets._description: Fixed-dollar or EBITDA-percentage baskets — sized at closing, grow only via grower formulation.

credit_facility_debt.description: Debt under the credit agreement itself (initial TL, revolver, incremental, DDTL, refinancing)

general_debt_basket.description: Uncircumscribed catch-all basket. Greater of fixed dollar / % EBITDA (grower).

capital_lease_purchase_money.description: Obligations under capital leases and purchase money financing

non_guarantor_debt.description: Debt at non-loan party restricted subsidiaries — structurally senior to credit facility
non_guarantor_debt.typical_sizing: 10-15% EBITDA (standalone or shared with acquisition debt)
non_guarantor_debt.risk: Structurally senior — non-guarantor creditors get paid before credit facility in enforcement

earnout_seller_notes.description: Deferred purchase price, seller notes, earn-outs from acquisitions
earnout_seller_notes.treatment_split: If classified as 'Indebtedness': capped. If NOT 'Indebtedness': no cap (UMM/BSL aggressive)

layer_2_ratio_baskets._description: Unlimited capacity subject to pro forma leverage tests — the infinite capacity layer.

ratio_debt.description: Unlimited debt outside the credit agreement subject to leverage test
ratio_debt.prevalence: 0/62 in DealData (empty field — embedded in IED and acquisition debt fields)
ratio_debt.typical: Shared ratio with incremental; FLLR for pari, total net for junior/unsecured

incremental_equivalent_debt.description: Side-car debt issuance outside credit agreement that mirrors incremental terms

incurred_acquisition_debt.description: Debt incurred 'in connection with' permitted acquisitions — ratio-based or fixed

assumed_acquisition_debt.description: Pre-existing target debt assumed (not incurred in contemplation of acquisition)
assumed_acquisition_debt.typical_sizing: Small fixed basket (10-15% EBITDA) or unlimited if ratio-tested

layer_3_conversion_baskets._description: Baskets that convert non-debt capacity (equity, AA, RP) into debt capacity.

contribution_debt.description: Debt equal to a percentage of post-closing equity contributions

aa_basket_debt.description: Debt incurred using Available Amount builder capacity
aa_basket_debt.prevalence: Embedded in 'Other Debt Baskets' field (59/62 populated)
aa_basket_debt.mechanism: Converts retained ECF capacity → debt incurrence capacity

rp_capacity_debt.description: Debt incurred using unused Restricted Payment capacity
rp_capacity_debt.mechanism: Converts unused leakage capacity → leverage capacity

redesignation_mechanics.description: Ability to redesignate capacity from one basket to another
redesignation_mechanics.aggressive: RP, Investment, AA capacity all reallocable to incremental

capacity_source_edges._description: Edges where non-debt capacity converts INTO debt capacity — the conversion layer that makes the indebtedness covenant interact with the leakage system.

aa_builder_to_debt.description: Available Amount builder capacity can be used to incur debt, converting leakage capacity into leverage capacity. This completes the AA→Indebtedness feedback loop: retained ECF builds AA → AA capacity incurs debt → debt proceeds generate cash → cash builds more ECF.

quantitative_parameters.aa_builder_growth_rate: ~10-15% EBITDA/year retained ECF at 50% sweep → equivalent debt incurrence capacity
quantitative_parameters.cumulative_year5: ~65-130% of single-year EBITDA in cumulative AA capacity potentially convertible to debt
quantitative_parameters.structural_requirement: Typically must be unsecured (Review Template Row 84) — but 'can automatically be secured' in aggressive deals

failure_modes: Circular capacity: AA builds debt → debt proceeds generate cash → cash builds ECF → ECF builds more AA → more debt capacity
If AA basket debt can be secured: pari passu dilution of first lien recovery without incremental test or MFN
Leverage spiral: AA-funded debt incurrence raises actual leverage while EBITDA addbacks mask the increase
aa_builder_to_debt.negotiation_sensitivity: CRITICAL where present — converts a capped leakage mechanism into uncapped leverage capacity.

rp_capacity_to_debt.description: Unused Restricted Payment capacity can be redesignated to incur debt. This makes the RP and indebtedness covenants partially fungible — capacity not used for dividends can be used for borrowing.

quantitative_parameters.typical_unused_rp: If sponsor takes minimal RPs: 15-50% of EBITDA/year in unused general + AA capacity → available for debt conversion
quantitative_parameters.accumulation: RP capacity accumulates year over year (especially builder components) — can create substantial conversion pool

rp_capacity_to_debt.mechanism: Learning Material: 'Available RP Capacity Amount... minus the sum of the amount utilized to (A) make Restricted Payments and (B) incur Indebtedness pursuant to Section 10.1(w).' The same capacity pool funds EITHER dividends or debt — not both.
failure_modes: Sponsor defers RPs in early years to build debt conversion capacity, then uses debt proceeds later
Invisible capacity: bank tracks RP usage but not the unused capacity being quietly converted to debt
Combined with AA basket debt: total conversion capacity = AA + RP + Investment unused = massive potential debt
rp_capacity_to_debt.negotiation_sensitivity: HIGH — Banks should track conversion capacity as part of total debt capacity analysis.

equity_to_contribution_debt.description: Post-closing equity injections create 1:1 (or 2:1 in aggressive deals) debt capacity. This leverages the equity contribution — turning a dollar of equity into a dollar of additional debt.

quantitative_parameters.multiplier: 100% standard (1:1 equity → debt). Aggressive BSL: potentially 200% (1:2)
quantitative_parameters.security: Must be unsecured in standard deals (PC line 402)
quantitative_parameters.time_limit: Typically no outside date for incurrence (UMM/BSL)

ground_truth.geneva: 100% of cash contributions and FMV of in-kind contributions (Section 6.01(a)(xxvii))

failure_modes: Equity → contribution debt → debt proceeds → RP distribution → re-contribute equity → more contribution debt (circularity)
FMV of in-kind contributions: subjective valuation creates inflated debt capacity
200% multiplier: each dollar of equity creates two dollars of leverage — amplifies risk
equity_to_contribution_debt.negotiation_sensitivity: MODERATE — 100% is standard. Push back on 200%, FMV of non-cash, and secured contribution debt.

general_debt_to_incremental.description: Unused general debt basket capacity can be reallocated to increase incremental borrowing capacity. This expands the free-and-clear basket beyond its nominal sizing.

quantitative_parameters.prevalence: 7/62 deals (11%) allow this reallocation — aggressive feature
quantitative_parameters.general_basket_median: 25% EBITDA — if fully unused, adds 25% EBITDA to incremental F&C basket
quantitative_parameters.combined_impact: Incremental F&C (100% EBITDA standard) + general debt reallocation (25% EBITDA) = 125% EBITDA in total unconditioned incremental capacity

failure_modes: Borrower intentionally avoids using general basket to maximize incremental reallocation
Combined with AA reallocation: general + AA + RP unused all flowing to incremental
Bank negotiates tight incremental F&C but general debt reallocation undoes the constraint
general_debt_to_incremental.negotiation_sensitivity: HIGH — General debt reallocation to incremental is an aggressive feature. Resist in LMM/CMM.

structural_constraint_edges._description: Conditions and structural limitations that gate debt incurrence.

leverage_gates_ratio_debt.from: Ratio Debt / IED / Acquisition Debt (ratio prong)
leverage_gates_ratio_debt.description: All ratio-based debt capacity is UNLIMITED subject to pro forma leverage test. Since EBITDA is the denominator, EBITDA inflation directly increases ratio debt capacity — this is the EBITDA multiplier effect applied to debt creation.

first_lien_net.usage: Pari passu secured debt (dominant in private credit)
first_lien_net.advantage_for_borrower: Excludes junior/unsecured debt + cash netting → easier to satisfy

total_net.advantage_for_lender: Captures all debt → harder to pass test

no_worse_prong.description: Incurrence permitted if leverage no worse than immediately before giving effect
no_worse_prong.bank_position: Typically rejected including in UMM/BSLR (PC line 383)
no_worse_prong.risk: Allows infinite debt at any leverage — no absolute ceiling

fccr_prong.description: Fixed charge coverage ratio alternative to leverage test

ebitda_multiplier_effect.mechanism: 10% EBITDA addback → leverage improves by ~0.5x on a 5x levered deal → unlocks ratio debt capacity that can be incurred pari passu
ebitda_multiplier_effect.cascading: EBITDA inflation improves the leverage test AND increases EBITDA-denominated fixed baskets simultaneously — double benefit from single manipulation
ebitda_multiplier_effect.corpus_exposure: 42% of deals have uncapped EBITDA addbacks (financial_definitions analysis) — unlimited EBITDA inflation potential

failure_modes: EBITDA addback manipulation passes incurrence test without real deleveraging
Pro forma EBITDA for acquisitions satisfies test before target earnings materialize
FLLR metric: 1-2x more favorable than total leverage → trivializes the gate
No-worse prong: debt incurrence at existing leverage always permitted, creating infinite capacity at any level
Multiple ratio debt incurrences in same period: each pro forma test ignores subsequently incurred debt
leverage_gates_ratio_debt.negotiation_sensitivity: CRITICAL — The ratio test is the ONLY constraint on unlimited debt capacity. Metric type and test level determine whether the constraint has teeth.

mfn_constrains_new_debt.description: Most Favored Nation protection ensures new pari debt cannot price significantly above existing facilities. Without MFN, borrower could issue cheaper-than-existing debt, economically diluting existing lenders.

quantitative_parameters.trigger_cushion: 50 bps universal (47/62 deals, 96% at 50 bps per incremental analysis)
quantitative_parameters.bank_preferred: 50 bps MFN for life of existing facilities (DLS Row 11)
quantitative_parameters.aggressive_sunset: MFN sunset at 12-18 months post-closing in UMM/BSL deals
quantitative_parameters.no_sunset: No sunset is the PC standard even for Aggressive UMM/BSLR

scope_by_debt_type.pari_notes_ied: MFN should apply — DLS says 'No MFN on pari notes' as bank alternative, but PC says MFN applies
scope_by_debt_type.junior_unsecured: MFN generally does NOT apply (different market, different risk profile)
scope_by_debt_type.revolving: MFN generally does NOT apply to revolver pricing

failure_modes: MFN sunset: after 12-18 months, new pari debt can price at any level
MFN carveouts: refinancing debt, revolving facilities, secured notes may be excluded
All-in yield definition: excluding certain fees from yield calculation narrows MFN's bite
Delayed draw: DDTL commitments may be carved out of MFN scope
mfn_constrains_new_debt.negotiation_sensitivity: HIGH — MFN scope, sunset, and yield definition are among the top-5 incremental/IED negotiation items.

maturity_wal_constrains_debt.description: Inside-maturity restrictions prevent new debt from maturing before existing facilities, which would create de facto structural seniority through earlier repayment. WAL restrictions prevent high-amortization circumvention.

quantitative_parameters.bank_preferred: No inside maturity except customary bridges and escrow arrangements (PC line 248)
quantitative_parameters.aggressive_umm_bsl: Inside maturity basket of 50-100% EBITDA (PC line 249)
quantitative_parameters.standard_maturity_floor: 91 days after existing TL latest maturity (common formulation)

failure_modes: Inside maturity basket: 50-100% EBITDA of debt can mature before existing — creates massive structural seniority
Bridge financing exception exploited: 'customary bridge' extended indefinitely
WAL manipulation: low amortization masks high balloon payment that effectively matures debt early
Maturity restriction applied only to final maturity, not amortization schedule
maturity_wal_constrains_debt.negotiation_sensitivity: HIGH — Inside maturity is a structural seniority mechanism. The basket size (50-100% EBITDA) determines how much debt can be structurally senior.

no_eod_gate_on_incurrence.description: Debt incurrence is generally conditioned on no existing Event of Default. However, the scope of EoD that blocks incurrence varies by market segment and debt type.

full_no_eod.description: Any default or EoD blocks all debt incurrence
full_no_eod.protectiveness: Highest — prevents debt buildup during distress

payment_bankruptcy_only.description: Only payment default or bankruptcy EoD blocks incurrence
payment_bankruptcy_only.prevalence: Common in UMM/BSL for acquisition-related debt
payment_bankruptcy_only.evidence: Viavi BSL: 'if i/c/w an Acquisition Transaction then no payment/bankruptcy EoD'
payment_bankruptcy_only.protectiveness: Moderate — allows debt incurrence during financial covenant default

lct_override.description: Limited Condition Transaction provisions freeze conditions at signing, not closing
lct_override.prevalence: 62/62 deals have LCT provisions (53 unique variations per reps_conditions analysis)
lct_override.risk: Conditions tested at signing of acquisition agreement → EoD could arise between signing and closing without blocking debt incurrence

failure_modes: LCT freezes conditions: EoD arises between signing and closing but incurrence proceeds anyway
Payment/bankruptcy only: borrower incurs debt during financial covenant default (most common default type)
Cross-default not triggered because material debt threshold exceeds basket sizes
no_eod_gate_on_incurrence.negotiation_sensitivity: MODERATE — EoD gate is standard but LCT override and scope limitations are heavily negotiated.

mirror_covenant_edges._description: Edges where the indebtedness covenant mechanically interacts with parallel covenants — liens, investments, financial covenant.

indebtedness_mirrors_liens.description: The liens covenant is a DERIVATIVE covenant — its basket structure mechanically mirrors the indebtedness covenant. Every debt basket needs a corresponding lien permission to be secured. This creates the potential for both gaps (debt permitted but unsecurable) and over-inclusiveness (liens permitted without corresponding debt).

structural_parallel.general_debt_basket: General liens basket mirrors general debt basket sizing
structural_parallel.ratio_debt: Ratio liens mirror ratio debt (tied to same leverage test)

critical_divergence_points.ica_authority: KCT Cat 4: Agent can subordinate existing liens without lender vote — a sacred rights issue
critical_divergence_points.non_collateral_liens: KCT Cat 4: Uncapped liens on non-collateral assets strip recovery value
critical_divergence_points.lien_perfection: KCT Cat 4: Broad carveouts for lien loss/priority loss undermine entire security framework

indebtedness_mirrors_liens.bank_position: PC line 407: 'Avoid having both a general liens basket and a crossing lien to general debt basket.' Prefer single unified debt+lien permission.
failure_modes: Lien basket broader than debt basket: liens granted for obligations that aren't permitted indebtedness
Debt basket broader than lien basket: debt permitted but only as unsecured (may be intended feature)
Cross-reference errors: debt basket references wrong lien clause or vice versa
ICA allows pari liens without lender consent: new pari creditors dilute existing first lien recovery
indebtedness_mirrors_liens.negotiation_sensitivity: HIGH — Liens/debt coordination is fundamental. Misalignment creates either leakage or unintended structural seniority.

debt_exclusions_from_fincov.description: Certain debt baskets may be excluded from the financial covenant leverage calculation, meaning the maintenance test underreports actual leverage. The borrower's true leverage can significantly exceed the covenant-tested leverage.

excluded_baskets.kct_flagged: KCT Cat 1 Item 5: freebie, non-guarantor debt basket, general debt basket, acquisition debt basket — all potentially excluded
typical_exclusions: Surety bonds and letters of credit

quantitative_impact.conservative: If only cap lease/PM excluded: ~23% EBITDA of debt invisible to covenant test
quantitative_impact.typical: If general basket also excluded: ~48% EBITDA invisible (23% cap lease + 25% general)
quantitative_impact.aggressive: If non-guarantor and acquisition also excluded: ~73%+ EBITDA invisible — maintenance test misses nearly 1x EBITDA of debt

failure_modes: Total leverage = 6x but covenant-tested leverage = 4x (2x of 'invisible' debt)
Borrower incurs maximum excluded debt → covenant cushion looks healthy → actual leverage is distressed
Cross-default threshold set based on covenant leverage, not actual leverage
debt_exclusions_from_fincov.negotiation_sensitivity: HIGH — KCT Cat 1 Item 5. Debt exclusion scope directly determines the financial covenant's real-world effectiveness.

intercompany_debt_investments.description: Intercompany loans to non-loan parties consume BOTH the intercompany debt basket AND the investment basket (via shared cap). This prevents double-dipping but creates sizing complexity.
intercompany_debt_investments.mechanism: PC line 398: 'Intercompany loans to non-Loan Parties capped/shared baskets with investments in non Loan Parties.' A loan from the borrower to a non-guarantor sub is simultaneously: (1) permitted debt under the intercompany basket, and (2) a permitted investment in a non-loan party.

lme_protection.subordination: LME Provision Language: 'any intercompany debt incurred under any debt basket that is owed by a loan party to a nonloan party subsidiary be subordinated to the loans'
lme_protection.double_dip_blocker: Review Template Row 71: All intercompany debt by loan parties to nonloan parties must be subordinated — prevents structural seniority via intercompany route

failure_modes: Intercompany debt NOT subordinated: non-loan party subsidiary becomes structurally senior creditor
Shared cap consumed by intercompany but investment basket has separate capacity — borrower uses both
Intercompany note required but not actually pledged — LME risk if non-loan party refuses to cooperate
intercompany_debt_investments.negotiation_sensitivity: MODERATE — Standard provision but subordination and pledging requirements are the critical protections.

earnout_classification.description: Whether earnouts are classified as 'Indebtedness' determines whether they consume debt basket capacity. If excluded from indebtedness, they may consume investment or RP capacity instead — or nothing at all.

if_indebtedness.consequence: Must fit within a debt basket. Capped, measured at maximum possible obligation.
if_indebtedness.bank_preferred: PC: 'earnouts should always be debt for the negative covenant (with a corresponding basket; measured at maximum possible obligation)'

if_not_indebtedness.consequence: No cap needed. May be treated as investment or ignored entirely.

subordination.cmm_lmm: May require subordination terms: not cash pay, no covenants, later maturity, at Holdco

failure_modes: Earnouts excluded from Indebtedness: unlimited seller debt with no basket consumption
Earnout payments treated as RDPs: consume RP/RDP capacity that could otherwise fund dividends
Maximum obligation measurement: if earnout capped at 100% EBITDA, that capacity is reserved even if payment likely to be 20% EBITDA
earnout_classification.negotiation_sensitivity: MODERATE — Classification as Indebtedness is the key gate. Once classified, standard basket mechanics apply.

lct_gates_incurrence.description: LCT provisions freeze incurrence test conditions at the signing date of an acquisition agreement, not the closing date. This means conditions may be satisfied at signing but violated by closing — and the debt is still incurred.

quantitative_parameters.unique_variations: 53 unique LCT formulations across 62 deals (reps_conditions analysis)
quantitative_parameters.typical_gap: 30-90 days between signing and closing of an acquisition

lct_gates_incurrence.mechanism: Sungard conditionality framework: borrower elects LCT → all incurrence tests (leverage, no EoD, reps) tested at signing → if conditions deteriorate between signing and closing, incurrence still proceeds. This is by design — enables borrowers to commit to acquisitions without closing-day risk.
failure_modes: Leverage deteriorates between signing and closing: debt incurred at higher-than-tested leverage
EoD arises post-signing: debt incurred despite active Event of Default
Multiple LCT elections in same period: each tested separately without considering others
lct_gates_incurrence.negotiation_sensitivity: MODERATE — LCT is market standard but the scope (which tests are frozen) and the overlap with other conditions are heavily negotiated.

reclassification_edges._description: Edges where capacity can be redesignated from one basket or covenant to another.

free_and_clear_to_ratio.description: Debt incurred under fixed-dollar baskets (free-and-clear, prepayment prong) can be redesignated to the ratio prong, freeing up the fixed basket for reuse.
free_and_clear_to_ratio.mechanism: Review Template Row 30: 'Able to redesignate starter and prepayment prongs to the ratio prong.' One-way: fixed → ratio. This restores the fixed basket's full capacity while the debt is reclassified as ratio debt.

quantitative_impact.free_and_clear_restored: Up to 100% EBITDA of F&C basket capacity restored after redesignation
quantitative_impact.total_debt_impact: First incurrence uses F&C (no leverage test). Redesignate to ratio → F&C restored → incur again using F&C. Total debt = 2x the nominal F&C basket if ratio test continuously satisfied.

failure_modes: Infinite reload: F&C incurrence → redesignate to ratio → restore F&C → incur again → redesignate again
Ratio test satisfied by EBITDA addbacks → redesignation occurs at inflated leverage
Bank tracks F&C usage but not redesignation — capacity appears exhausted but has been restored
free_and_clear_to_ratio.negotiation_sensitivity: HIGH — Redesignation is the mechanism that makes nominal basket caps meaningless. Bank should limit redesignation frequency or require separate ratio test.

cross_covenant_reallocation.description: In aggressive deals, unused capacity from leakage covenants (RP, investments) and the Available Amount can be reallocated to incremental or general debt capacity. This is the broadest form of cross-covenant fungibility.

general_debt_to_incremental.capacity: Up to 25% EBITDA (general basket median) added to incremental F&C

aa_to_incremental.prevalence: Learning Material + Review Template — aggressive feature
aa_to_incremental.capacity: AA builder capacity (potentially 65-130% of single-year EBITDA cumulative) → incremental

rp_to_debt.prevalence: Learning Material: 'Available RP Capacity Amount... to incur Indebtedness'

cross_covenant_reallocation.combined_conversion_risk: If all pathways active: total convertible capacity = unused general (25% EBITDA) + unused AA (65%+ EBITDA cumulative) + unused RP (varies) + unused investments (varies). Can easily exceed 100% of EBITDA in additional debt capacity beyond nominal baskets.
failure_modes: Invisible capacity buildup: bank tracks each covenant individually but not the combined reallocation pool
Sponsor strategically defers leakage to accumulate conversion capacity → single large debt incurrence
No MFN or maturity restrictions on reallocated capacity debt (falls outside incremental constraints)
cross_covenant_reallocation.negotiation_sensitivity: CRITICAL — Cross-covenant reallocation is the most structurally dangerous feature in the indebtedness covenant. Bank should resist or cap total reallocation.

stacking_risk_edges._description: The combinatorial maximum problem — how individual baskets stack to create total debt capacity far exceeding any single basket's intent.

basket_stacking_architecture.description: KCT Category 2 explicitly identifies the basket stacking problem: individual basket sizes are building blocks; total capacity is determined by the combinatorial maximum — not the sum. Baskets that can be simultaneously used create multiplicative debt capacity.

vector_1_core_stacking.description: General debt + incremental F&C + ratio debt (if all maximized simultaneously)
components: Ratio debt: UNLIMITED (subject to leverage test)
vector_1_core_stacking.kct_items: Cat 2 Items 1-3: identify stacking of pari and structurally senior debt

vector_2_acquisition_triple_count.description: Contribution debt + acquisition debt + assumed debt (triple-count for same acquisition)
components: Incurred acquisition debt: ratio-tested (unlimited if test passes)
Risk: all three incurred for same acquisition → triple-counted capacity
vector_2_acquisition_triple_count.kct_items: Cat 2 Item 4: contribution debt stacking with acquisition baskets

vector_3_conversion_stacking.description: AA basket debt + RP capacity debt + investment-to-incremental reallocation
components: AA basket debt: up to cumulative AA builder (65-130% EBITDA over 5 years)
RP capacity debt: unused RP capacity
Investment reallocation: unused investment capacity → incremental
Risk: leakage capacity converts to leverage capacity on top of direct debt baskets

vector_4_non_guarantor_concentration.description: Multiple baskets funding non-guarantor entities (structurally senior debt)
components: General basket at non-guarantors: uncapped in some deals
Intercompany loans to non-loan parties: shared with investment cap
Acquisition debt non-guarantor cap: shared or separate
Risk: total structurally senior debt far exceeds any single non-guarantor cap
vector_4_non_guarantor_concentration.kct_items: Cat 2 Item 6: structurally senior debt concentration

combinatorial_maximum_estimate.conservative_lmm: Credit facility + 15-20% EBITDA general + 100% EBITDA F&C + ratio = ~120% EBITDA fixed + unlimited ratio + facility
combinatorial_maximum_estimate.typical_cmm: Facility + 25% EBITDA general + 100% EBITDA F&C + contribution debt + ratio = ~125% EBITDA fixed + unlimited ratio + facility + contribution
combinatorial_maximum_estimate.aggressive_umm_bsl: Facility + 40% general + 100% F&C + ratio + conversion capacity (AA+RP) + contribution + inside maturity (50-100%) = ~240%+ EBITDA fixed + unlimited ratio + all conversion + facility

failure_modes: Bank negotiates individual baskets but doesn't track combinatorial maximum
Stacking occurs over time: year 1 uses F&C, year 2 adds ratio, year 3 adds conversion capacity — invisible escalation
Non-guarantor concentration: structurally senior debt across multiple baskets exceeds recovery expectations
Redesignation restores fixed baskets: actual debt far exceeds nominal basket caps
basket_stacking_architecture.negotiation_sensitivity: CRITICAL — KCT Category 2 is entirely dedicated to stacking risk. This is the primary structural risk in the indebtedness covenant.

ebitda_amplifier_on_debt.to: All Grower Baskets + All Ratio Tests
ebitda_amplifier_on_debt.description: EBITDA inflation simultaneously increases every grower basket (EBITDA-denominated) AND improves every leverage ratio (EBITDA as denominator). This is not one relationship — it is a systemic amplifier that cascades through the entire debt basket ecosystem.

grower_baskets: General debt: 25% EBITDA → grows with EBITDA
Capital lease: 23% EBITDA → grows with EBITDA
Non-guarantor cap: 10-15% EBITDA → grows with EBITDA
Inside maturity basket: 50-100% EBITDA → grows with EBITDA
ratio_tests: Incremental ratio prong → leverage improves → more ratio capacity
IED ratio test → leverage improves → more IED capacity
Acquisition debt ratio → leverage improves → more acquisition debt
ECF stepdowns → leverage improves → less sweep → more retained ECF → more AA → more conversion capacity

10pct_ebitda_addback.ratio_debt_unlock: Potentially unlimited additional debt if leverage improvement passes incurrence test

quantitative_cascade.cumulative: A single 10% EBITDA addback creates ~6% EBITDA in additional fixed basket capacity + potentially unlimited ratio debt + faster ECF stepdowns + more AA conversion capacity. The multiplicative effect is the true risk.

failure_modes: Uncapped addbacks (42% of corpus): unlimited EBITDA inflation → unlimited basket growth + unlimited ratio debt
Acquired EBITDA: bolt-on acquisition EBITDA added to denominator → capacity increases before earnings materialize
Cost savings addbacks: projected savings credited before realized → phantom capacity
ebitda_amplifier_on_debt.negotiation_sensitivity: CRITICAL — EBITDA is the master variable. Every addback discussion is simultaneously an indebtedness capacity discussion.

debt_sweep_backstop.description: The debt sweep is the backstop mechanism — if debt is incurred outside permitted baskets, 100% of proceeds must prepay the term loan, making unpermitted debt economically pointless.

quantitative_parameters.flow_rate: 100% of net cash proceeds from non-permitted debt issuance

failure_modes: Classification as 'Refinancing Facility' to avoid sweep — definitional gaming
No debt sweep at all (3/62 deals — Learning Material: flag if absent)
Refinancing debt used to upsize rather than replace — proceeds exceed existing debt
debt_sweep_backstop.negotiation_sensitivity: LOW — Universally standard, but classification of 'Permitted Debt' and 'Refinancing Facilities' matters.

cross_default_interaction.description: Cross-default provisions trigger an EoD in the credit agreement when the borrower defaults on other material debt. The material debt threshold must exceed individual basket sizes to avoid technical defaults from basket debt.

quantitative_parameters.threshold_range: Corpus range per EoD analysis: varies by deal size, typically 5-10% EBITDA
quantitative_parameters.alignment_risk: If general debt basket (25% EBITDA) exceeds cross-default threshold (5% EBITDA): a default on general basket debt triggers cross-default → EoD in credit agreement

failure_modes: Threshold too low: technical defaults on permitted basket debt trigger cross-default cascade
Threshold too high: borrower defaults on substantial debt without triggering cross-default
Material debt definition excludes certain basket debt types → cross-default blind to those defaults
cross_default_interaction.negotiation_sensitivity: MODERATE — Threshold alignment with basket sizes is a coordination exercise.

sale_leaseback_interaction.description: Sale-leaseback transactions sit at the intersection of three covenants: dispositions (asset sale), indebtedness (capital lease obligation created), and liens (purchase money/capital lease lien). Without coordination, sale-leaseback can be used to extract asset value while creating only capital lease obligations.
sale_leaseback_interaction.mechanism: Step 1: Sell asset (disposition basket consumption). Step 2: Lease back creates capital lease obligation (indebtedness basket consumption). Step 3: Lien on leased asset (liens basket consumption). Net effect: borrower receives cash but asset remains in use — economically equivalent to a secured loan against the asset.

market_treatment.bank_preferred: Capped and aligned across all three covenants

failure_modes: Uncapped sale-leaseback in UMM/BSL: unlimited cash extraction via asset monetization
Capital lease obligation excluded from financial covenant leverage test: invisible leverage
Disposition proceeds from sale-leaseback may not trigger asset sale sweep if structured as 'financing' rather than 'disposition'
sale_leaseback_interaction.negotiation_sensitivity: MODERATE — Standard provision in LMM/CMM but requires vigilance on cap and cross-covenant alignment in UMM/BSL.

infinite_capacity_system.description: The Indebtedness Covenant is designed as a LAYERED CAPACITY SYSTEM, not a hard cap. Layer 1 (fixed baskets) provides 130-190% of EBITDA in base capacity. Layer 2 (ratio baskets) adds UNLIMITED capacity subject to leverage test. Layer 3 (conversion baskets) adds cross-covenant capacity from AA, RP, and Investment sources. The combinatorial maximum of all three layers — especially when amplified by EBITDA addbacks — creates a theoretical capacity that vastly exceeds any single basket's nominal size. This is by design: the layered system gives borrowers flexibility while relying on the incurrence test as the ultimate constraint. The system fails when EBITDA manipulation makes the incurrence test trivially passable.
